Title: 5 tips for Rough-in Phase on New Construction. Electrical wiring.
Problem: Trim-out becomes difficult or error-prone because of poor rough‑in practices (misplaced/hidden wires, unlabeled boxes, wrong receptacle/fixture locations, premature panel make-up) leading to rework, safety risks, theft, or lost follow-up work.
Solution: Use consistent rough‑in practices: curl and stub wires into accessible stud locations and cabinets, label every box, photograph completed rough‑in, set appliance/fixture outlet heights (e.g., dryer), communicate desired stub locations to trades, avoid installing breakers or fully making up the panel on rough‑in, and standardize methods so trim‑out is easy, safe, and repeatable.
Subtopics: Rough‑in wiring best practices (curling/stubbing, accessible studs) (30%), Panel & breaker handling / temporary power prevention (do not make up panel) (25%), Labeling and photo documentation of rough‑in (15%), Fixture and receptacle placement & heights (vanity centering, dryer, under‑sink) (15%), Consistency and trim‑out planning (cookie‑cutter methods, contractor communication) (10%), Tools & methods (cut‑in boxes, tape/measuring, photo tools) (5%)

Title: How To Install Rough In Electricity In A New Construction House - Beginners Guide To Electrical
Problem: Installing rough-in electrical for a new-construction bedroom—placing and anchoring switch, receptacle and ceiling-fan boxes, running 12-2 and 12-3 cable, routing to the panel, and meeting outlet spacing and fastening requirements.
Solution: Mounted switch and receptacle boxes flush to studs, installed a saddle box on the rafter for the ceiling fan, drilled straight through studs and ran 12-2/12-3 NM cable (stapling within code distances), followed the 6‑12 outlet spacing rule, tied and crimped grounds, labeled cable runs, and routed the home-run to the panel for final termination after drywall.
Topics: Wiring (45%), Codes & Regulations (20%), Tools (15%), Planning (10%), Safety (10%)
Subtopics: Cable runs, box placement and wiring (35%), Outlet spacing / 6-12 NEC rule (20%), Tools & fasteners: drills, right-angle attachment, staples, wire strippers (15%), Ceiling fan saddle box & mounting (10%), Circuit planning (one circuit per bedroom) and labeling (10%), Grounding, stapling clearance and temporary panel safety (10%)

Problem: Completing the electrical rough-in for a new house—placing switches/outlets, running all wiring to the panel, and provisioning an EV (Tesla) plug.

Title: NEW BUILD TIPS: WHAT I WISH I KNEW BEFORE OUR ELECTRICAL APPOINTMENT | Watch This Before You Go!
Problem: Homebuyers often overlook the electrical design appointment when building a home, leading to missed outlet/lighting placement, insufficient pre-wiring for low-voltage systems or future upgrades, and costly retrofits later.
Solution: Prepare ahead and use the appointment to lock in locations and pre-wires: review each room's function and furniture layout, inspect the model home, plan outlet/switch/lighting placement (including hidden outlets, ceiling fan pre-wires, dedicated switches and dimmers), request low-voltage and future-proofing pre-wires (security, home automation, TV tunnels, generator/solar/central vacuum), document locations with photos/measures before drywall, and review the pricing sheet within the decision period.

Problem: Explaining and planning the basic electrical wiring for a garage/subpanel project (circuits, outlets, lights, three-way switches, correct wire/breaker pairing, grounding) so a DIYer can safely prepare for the actual installation.
Solution: A step-by-step verbal walkthrough and diagram-based overview: choice of Romex (12/2, 14/2, 14/3), matching wire gauge to breaker amperage, grounding and neutral bus separation in a subpanel, outlet and light wiring (including pigtails), and detailed explanation of three-way switch traveler wiring, plus safety reminders and promise of a follow-up video showing the physical wiring.

Title: 5 Tips for New Construction Electrical & Smart Lighting!
Problem: Deciding electrical choices and installation details for a new-build rough-in: wire gauge and breaker sizing, feeder material, air-sealing of penetrations, fixture and box selection, smart lighting integration, and how to instruct/bid electricians.
Solution: Used 12-2 copper throughout for 20 A circuits, ran a #2 copper feeder to a subpanel, specified one-hole-per-wire and pre-blocking to enable effective air sealing, selected Halo Bluetooth mesh smart lighting (hardwired keypads/switches and wafer-thin fixtures) and planned fixture locations on a reflected ceiling plan, used Arlington recessed and airtight boxes for exterior/party-use and sound/air control, and pre-wired dedicated 220V circuits (oven, HVAC, heated floor) while documenting choices for electrician bids.

Title: How to bend and install electrical conduit
Problem: Install a code-compliant metal conduit electrical rough-in in a small shed — including mounting steel boxes, drilling through studs/plates, bending conduit (90s, offsets, kicks), connecting and reaming conduit, and properly fastening/strapping — while making the process accessible to beginners.
Solution: Step-by-step tutorial: mount 1900 bracket steel boxes at standard heights with exterior-rated deck screws; lay out circuit flow and mark holes; drill through studs/plates; install zinc set-screw connectors and ream conduit ends; measure and bend 90s and offsets using bender stub offsets (accounting for bender-specific measurements), cut to length (use 16" on-center increments to simplify runs), assemble with couplings, apply kicks to position conduit in holes, strap conduit to studs, and tighten connectors — plus tool tips (Klein pouch, channel locks, marker) and code-aware fastener selection to avoid galvanic corrosion.
Subtopics: Conduit bending & offsets (30%), Box mounting & placement (20%), Measurement & layout planning (20%), Fasteners, connectors & reaming (15%), Drilling holes, through-plates & strapping (15%)

Solution: Conduct a room-by-room rough inspection checklist: verify outlet placement (one per wall, kitchen sink/laundry requirements, exterior/condenser outlets), confirm Romex routing and securing (staples within 12", limit wires per hole), ensure smoke/CO alarm boxes and attic service outlet for mechanical units, check panel (neutral/ground separation, torque), require nail guards/metal plates and sealed penetrations, and confirm NEC-based compliance (noting NEC17 → NEC20 transition).

Title: 5 CLEVER Electrical Tricks Everyone Should Know
Problem: The transcript addresses common DIY electrical connection problems: unreliable wire-nut connections, weak/incorrect splices, damaged power cords near plugs, poor screw-terminal terminations, and inefficient/unsafe stripping tools and methods.
Solution: Replace wire nuts with visible lever-nuts for reliable splices; use a hooked/Western‑Union style splice plus heat‑shrink for strong wire repairs; cut off and fit a new replacement plug (match wire colors to screw colors) instead of replacing whole cords; orient hooks "with the grain" or use fork connectors for screw terminals; and use universal wire strippers to consistently strip many gauges without nicking conductors.
Subtopics: Connectors & terminals (lever-nuts, wire-nuts, screw/fork connectors) (30%), Splicing & cord repair techniques (hook/knotted splice, heat-shrink, plug replacement) (30%), Wire stripping tools & methods (universal wire strippers, depth stops, adjustment) (20%), Best practices & safety tips (orientation "with the grain", secure clamps, visual verification) (20%)

Title: How to bend EMT The offset shorts #fyp #electrical #diy
Problem: Creating an EMT conduit offset to clear an obstruction (a 2x4) and maintain proper spacing and support before a box.
Solution: Use an EMT bender to make an offset using a 30° (or 22°) bend. Multiply the obstruction thickness by the bend multiplier (2) to get spacing between bends (3.5" × 2 = 7"). Bend up to 30°, realign, make the second bend to form the offset, finish with the foot of the bender, and strap the conduit at the calculated distance before the box.

Title: Fish Electrical Wire in Walls: The Secret to Easy Fishing! Running wires through existing walls.
Problem: Fishing and routing Romex (NM) cable through finished ceilings/walls into an electrical box (attic-to-box and basement-to-box) without cutting drywall or damaging finishes, and locating the correct stud/box position.
Solution: Drill a small pilot hole in the ceiling above the intended box, push the Romex up into the attic as a guide, tape a weighted chain to the cable (tapered with tape) and drop it down above the box, grab and pull the chain into the box with pliers to draw the Romex through. Use a steel box to secure the cable. From the basement, drill an angled pilot through the baseboard to locate the stud bottom, then drill up into the wall and fish the cable the same way. Mark chain length with tape, taper ends to prevent snags, and use needle-nose pliers to finish pulling.
Subtopics: Cable fishing / wire routing (30%), Box selection & securing (20%), Drill technique & pilot holes (10%), Pulling tools (chain, fish, pliers) (10%), Measurement & marking (8%), Route planning & avoiding obstacles (7%), Protecting finishes (carpet/baseboard) (8%), Securing cable / strain relief practices (7%)

Title: Electrical Wiring Process - Part 9 - Installing a Light with a switch leg - Come wire with us
Problem: Wire a light fixture controlled by a single‑pole switch when the power feed enters the fixture/junction box (need a switch leg / switch loop) while meeting code and safe grounding/neutral practices.
Solution: Run 14/3 cable from the fixture box to the switch. Twist and nut grounds together and bond to the switch ground (no pigtail to fixture if it has no ground terminal). Tie incoming and outgoing neutrals together in the fixture box and add a pigtail to the fixture neutral; cap the neutral in the switch box. Connect incoming hot (black) to the black conductor to feed the switch, connect the red return from the switch to the fixture hot (gold). Terminate switch wires on the two switch screws (either way), secure all connections with wire nuts, tighten terminal hooks clockwise, fold and pack wires, and mount device and fixture.

Title: Electrical Designing of High Rise Building G+10 | Electrical Design Course
Problem: Design the electrical distribution for a G+10 residential high‑rise: calculate total connected load and peak demand, size the transformer, select circuit breakers for the transformer and main/meter panels, size individual flat MCBs, and produce a single‑line diagram while respecting meter standards and panel limits.
Solution: Stepwise design: compute common loads (lifts, pumps, lighting) and flat loads (energy‑meter ratings) and sum to total connected load (790 kW); apply demand factor (70%) to get peak demand (553 kW); compute transformer kVA = kW / pf (553/0.8 ≈ 692 kVA) and choose an 800 kVA dry indoor transformer; convert kVA to amperes and select a 1250 A triple‑pole ACB for the transformer. Divide meters into four meter panels (max 30 meters each), compute each panel’s connected load, apply demand factor and kW→A conversion (×1.9), and select MCCBs (panel1 = 250 A, panels2–4 = 400 A). Size individual flat MCBs with safety factor (2): 2BHK 40 A 4‑pole, 3BHK 50 A 4‑pole, 4BHK 63 A 4‑pole; common load 200 A MCCB. Produce the single‑line: 11 kV/440 V dry transformer (RYB N), 1250 A ACB, main LT panel feeding four meter panels per the above.
Subtopics: Load calculation (25%), Transformer sizing (12%), Single-line diagram & documentation (8%), Tutorial / Instruction (25%), Demand factor & meter standards (15%), Circuit breaker & panel selection (15%)

Title: Basic Electrical Maintenance for Commercial Facilities
Problem: Replacing faulty or unsafe electrical outlets and wiring them correctly (including maintaining circuit continuity, separating switched receptacles, and ensuring proper grounding) while avoiding shock or fire hazards.
Solution: Wear PPE and follow lockout/tagout; verify power is off with a voltage tester/multimeter; remove faceplate and outlet; compare old and new outlets and break the feed-through tab if separate control is needed; disconnect wires, trim and strip to ~1/2" and form loops; attach wires clockwise under terminal screws or into screw-clamps (hot to brass, neutral to silver, ground to green); pigtail grounds when required (especially with metal boxes); tuck wires, secure outlet and cover plate, then restore power and test.
Subtopics: Outlet terminals, polarity, and tab removal (30%), Grounding and bonding/pigtails (20%), Receptacle replacement procedure (step sequence) (20%), PPE and lockout/tagout (15%), Wire preparation and hand tools (strippers, pliers, testers) (10%), Testing/verification with voltage tester/multimeter (5%)

Title: Grounding and Bonding an Electrical Panel
Problem: Need to properly ground and bond an electrical panel — install ground rods, run and protect the grounding conductor into the garage, and bond the neutral bus to the panel so the grounding system is continuous.
Solution: Drive two 5/8" ground rods (minimum 6' apart) using a demolition hammer and sledge as needed; clamp a copper‑plated grounding conductor to each rod with grounding clamps, route the conductor through a hole in the sheathing into a junction box/conduit with a 90° entry, seal the pass‑through with silicone, secure the conductor up to the panel, terminate to the neutral bus with a connector, and install the bonding screw to bond the neutral bus to the panel enclosure.

Title: HOW to calculate a large service!!   parallel runs #shorts #fyp #electrical
Problem: Determine how to size a 1200 A service using available 500 kcmil conductors and ensure the conductors, overcurrent protection, and equipment meet rating/standard sizes and the engineer’s plans.
Solution: Use conductor ampacity (500 kcmil = 310 A at 75°C), multiply by the number of parallel conductors (4 × 310 A = >1200 A), choose the standard 1200 A equipment size, verify overcurrent device/equipment ratings meet code requirements, and confirm the installation matches the engineer’s plans.

Title: Electrical plans - The EASY way
Problem: Setting up a combined electrical and reflected ceiling plan in ArchiCAD — organizing layers/legends/views, placing fixtures/switches/outlets, creating wiring paths and ensuring constructible spacing and routing.
Solution: Create a dedicated layer combination and electrical legend layer; duplicate the floor plan view into an electrical/RC plan view and apply the electrical layer combo; hide non‑relevant layers (dimensions, text); use a semi‑transparent fill to de‑emphasize the base plan; create reference grids with polylines and the multiply/distribute tool; place symbols from the legend, duplicate/mirror as needed; draw switch-to-fixture paths with the spline tool and set display order; correct layer assignments and follow placement rules (avoid lights over fans, switches near doors, ensure cavity slider routing for cabling).
Subtopics: ArchiCAD layer/combo/view workflow (30%), Lighting & fixture placement (15%), Switch & outlet placement (10%), Layer management & view duplication (8%), Multiply/distribute, spline & selection tools (7%), Power point distribution & routing considerations (12%), Cavity slider cable routing (8%), Avoid light-over-fan strobing & switch accessibility (10%)

Title: Electrical Designing of G+5 Building with calculations & Single Line Diagram |Total load calculation
Problem: Design the electrical distribution for a G+5 residential building (loads for 3BHK and 4BHK flats plus common services), including correct load calculations, peak demand, transformer sizing, circuit breaker selection and preparation of a single-line diagram and meter schedule.
Solution: Follow five steps: (1) calculate total connected load (sum of flat loads and common loads) and apply a demand factor to get peak demand; (2) size the transformer (kVA = peak kW / power factor); (3) convert transformer kVA to current and select main MCCB; (4) calculate amperage per flat and common loads and select appropriate MCB/MCCB ratings for each; (5) prepare a single-line diagram showing transformer, meter panel, breakers and distribution to 31 meters.

Title: Electrical Design in building construction MEP  #mep #construction
Problem: Determining correct breaker and cable sizes and designing distribution boards that meet load requirements and local/international standards while accounting for voltage drop, ambient temperature, installation method, grouping, power factor and diversity.
Solution: Step-by-step method: calculate load current from power and power factor (single-phase and three-phase formulas); pick the next standard breaker rating; compute cable current-carrying requirement (Id) using 1.15 or applicable grouping factor; select cable size from manufacturer/DO‑CAP charts; compute voltage drop (mv × I × L / 1000) and ensure it meets the 4% (or project) limit; apply ambient-temperature and installation correction factors; iterate to a larger cable if voltage drop or correction factors fail; follow relevant standards (BS/EN/IEC, ADDC/DEWA) and apply diversity factors and enclosure/module sizing rules. Presenter used examples, shortcuts (e.g., approx. breaker = 2× kW for quick sizing) and Q&A clarifications.

Solution: Treat the PV system as an integral part of the building electrical installation and adapt the design: determine proper connection points, perform calculations that include PV production, size equipment accordingly, design protection schemes for inverter-interfaced DC/AC sources and multiple-source operation — guidance to be provided in a dedicated PV self-consumption video series.
Subtopics: Inverter and PV system characteristics (30%), System design, connection point selection and sizing (30%), Protection, grounding and multi-source safety measures (20%), Training/documentation and informational outreach (20%)

Title: The Best Power System for Vans | Watch Before You Buy Van Electrical System
Problem: Designing and installing a reliable, safe, high-capacity integrated lithium power system in a Sprinter van while managing charging sources, protecting the alternator and batteries, organizing wiring, and providing clear monitoring/troubleshooting for users.
Solution: Use an all-Victron system: three 200 Ah LiFePO4 batteries (600 Ah total), MPPT solar charge controller, Lynx BMS and Lynx distributor, smart shunt, MultiPlus 3000W inverter/charger, Cerbo GX + GX display and VRM for remote monitoring, proper fusing/breakers and current-limiting BMS for alternator protection, mount everything in an Infiniti power box with solid brackets and clean wire management, and recommend regular shore-power top-ups and use of the VRM/display for diagnostics.
Subtopics: System Components & Integration (Cerbo GX, VRM, MPPT, inverter, smart batteries) (40%), Wiring & Distribution (Lynx distributor, fuses, breakers, cable management) (25%), System Design & Installation Planning (battery sizing, mounting, power box layout, alternator selection) (20%), Protection & Monitoring (BMS current limiting, fuses, breakers, alarms, diagnostics) (15%)

Problem: Viewers (electrical engineers and graduates) need a concise overview of the most commonly used software for electrical design, simulation, development and prototyping, especially for power systems.

Subtopics: Software simulation & modeling (35%), Power system analysis (30%), Circuit simulation (15%), Protection & safety analysis (10%), Training & learning resources (10%)

Title: Complete Solar Panel Connection with Solar Charge Controller and Inverter @TheElectricalGuy
Problem: How to wire a solar panel system to charge a battery and power a bulb (or household lights), while protecting equipment and allowing AC loads via an inverter.
Solution: Use a solar charge controller between the panel and battery; install an MCB for overload/short-circuit protection and an SPD plus earthing for surge protection; connect panel +/– to controller terminals, connect battery to controller for charging and backup, draw DC loads from the controller’s DC outputs, and connect an inverter to the battery (or controller terminals) to power AC lamps—route inverter output through the home MCB for distribution.
Subtopics: Panel-to-controller and battery wiring (35%), Overcurrent protection (MCB) and surge protection (SPD) (25%), Earthing/grounding practices (10%), Charge controller and battery charging management (15%), Inverter (DC→AC) and load distribution (15%)

Title: Design Problem on transformer selection - Design, Management and Auditing of Electrical Systems
Problem: Determine the required kVA rating of a distribution transformer for a plant given four loads (with kW, power factor, efficiency, diversity factor, load factor) and identify which load needs power factor correction and the kVAR size required.
Solution: Compute kVA of each load using kVA = kW × load factor × diversity factor / (efficiency × power factor), sum kVA values, add 25% allowance for future expansion, and select the nearest standard transformer rating (chosen 2500 kVA, 11 kV/440 V, Δ-Y, ONAN). For power factor correction, calculate required kVAR for the low-PF load using Qc = P × (tan φ1 − tan φ2) and provide a capacitor bank connected across that load.
Subtopics: Load / kVA calculation (45%), Transformer selection and specifications (20%), Power factor correction (kVAR calculation and capacitor sizing) (15%), Future expansion / sizing margin (10%), Instructional demonstration / worked example (10%)

Title: Harmonics in Electrical Power Distribution Systems
Problem: Nonlinear loads (VFDs, UPS, rectifiers, electronic ballasts, etc.) cause harmonic distortion in electrical power distribution systems, leading to overheating, increased neutral currents, equipment maloperation, resonance, inaccurate metering and premature failures.
Solution: Follow IEEE‑519 limits at the point of common coupling, perform harmonic analysis and monitoring, and mitigate using engineered, coordinated measures such as passive/active harmonic filters, line reactors/isolation transformers, higher‑pulse rectifiers or active front‑end VFDs, relocation/removal of capacitor banks, and appropriate metering and design practices performed by qualified personnel.
Subtopics: Harmonic mitigation methods: filters, reactors, higher‑pulse drives, active front‑end (30%), Measurement & analysis tools: meters, scopes, simulation software, harmonic studies (15%), IEEE‑519 compliance & point of common coupling limits (30%), Harmonic studies, system modeling & coordinated design (15%), Equipment overheating, neutral currents & protection implications (10%)

Title: Online Battery Energy Storage System Design Training from Advance Electrical Design and Engineering
Problem: Determine the hospital's power and energy requirements (day/month), and size a battery energy storage system (BESS) to supply partial loads with one- and two-day backup while accounting for load types, power factor, battery efficiency/DoD and utility requirements.
Solution: Instructor derived total instantaneous power (sum of loads), converted to energy by multiplying by time (24 h) to get daily and monthly kWh, applied a 0.5 partial-load factor where specified, and included charging/discharging and safety multipliers (≈1.2 and 1.3) to compute required battery capacity. Example results: base load 62 kW → 1,488 kWh/day (37,200 kWh/month); partial-load (50%) 744 kWh → battery size ≈1,161 kWh (with margins). With planned expansion to 92 kW → 2,208 kWh/day (55,200 kWh/month); partial-load 1,104 kWh → single-day battery ≈1,723 kWh; two-day backup interpreted as two days backup + one operating → total BESS ≈5,169 kWh. Also covered PF concepts, PF correction (capacitors), on‑grid/off‑grid definitions, battery chemistries (lead‑acid vs lithium‑ion), and conversion to DC current at chosen battery voltage (e.g., 46 kW @ 240 V → ~191.7 A).
Topics: Planning (35%), Technology (30%), Education (20%), Codes & Regulations (10%), Safety (5%)
Subtopics: Load & energy calculations (30%), Battery sizing / BESS design and kWh→Ah conversions (25%), Power factor theory and correction (15%), On‑grid vs off‑grid integration and utility approvals (10%), Battery chemistry, efficiency & charge/discharge losses (10%), Thermal losses, DoD and safety margins (10%)

Title: WHY EARTHING IS NECESSARY IN ELECTRICAL SYSTEM?||FULLY EXPLAIN||
Problem: People receiving electric shocks from home appliances because the equipment frames or neutral are not properly connected to earth; lack of an effective earthing/grounding path exposes personnel and equipment to fault currents, lightning and voltage surges.
Solution: Provide a proper earthing (grounding) system — connect non-current-carrying parts and the supply neutral to earth via low-resistance conductors and electrodes so fault and surge currents safely flow to ground, preventing shocks and protecting equipment.

Title: Can Romex Cable be run Through Conduit? National Electrical Code Book
Problem: Confusion about whether NM (Romex) cable may be run inside conduit — homeowners and some electricians disagree, and inspectors flag improper installations (especially regarding underground/damp locations and conduit fill).
Solution: By NEC: NM cable can be run in conduit indoors if the conduit is not in a damp/wet location and conduit fill limits (Chapter 9) are met; it must not be used for underground runs (NEC 300.5 treats underground conduit as wet). Single NM runs are allowable when fill is correct; multiple runs may require derating. Best practice is to use individual THHN/THWN conductors for easier pulling and future work.
Subtopics: Conduit fill and derating requirements (30%), NM (Romex) permitted uses — indoor vs. underground/damp locations (25%), Relevant NEC references: Article 334, Article 300.5, Chapter 9 (20%), Recommendation to use individual conductors (THHN/THWN) as best practice (15%), Homeowner/inspector guidance and compliance advice (10%)

Problem: Guide and instructions for installing electrical conduit (metallic, EMT and PVC) for indoor, outdoor and underground runs while ensuring correct materials, routing, anchoring and basic safety.
Solution: Three step-by-step methods: install metallic rigid conduit from the panel using couplings and a bender; install EMT conduit with offsets, couplings, deburring and fish tape to pull wires; install PVC conduit for exterior/underground runs by drilling/pound fittings, solvent-welding joints, trenching to ~18" and securing with clamps — all with measuring, anchoring, and basic safety (power off, secure fittings).
Topics: Wiring (40%), Tools (20%), Planning (15%), Safety (15%), Codes & Regulations (10%)
Subtopics: Conduit installation methods (rigid/EMT/PVC) (30%), Tools & equipment (benders, fish tape, deburring tool, hacksaw, drill) (20%), Underground/trenching and PVC joining (15%), Mounting, anchoring and box/fitting installation (10%), Safety procedures (power disconnect, protection, secure fittings) (15%), Code-related requirements (minimum raceway size, burial depth) (10%)

Problem: Pulling multiple large-gauge conductors (#6 THWN) through long conduit runs with bends and LBs for a subpanel feed, encountering snags and needing to meet safe/Code-compliant termination at the subpanel.
Solution: Use fish tape(s) and a fish-tape puller/pulling machine, oversize the conduit, stagger and spiral-wrap (tape) the stripped conductors to a hook, join two fish tapes when stuck, use lubricant if needed, leave extra slack, follow burial depth and conduit fittings (LBs), and terminate wires with proper ground/neutral separation at the subpanel and install the 70A breaker.

Title: Bending PVC Conduit for Electrical Wiring

Title: Electrical Earthing System
Problem: Selecting and applying the proper grounding (earthing) method in industrial plants to protect people and equipment from fault currents, surges, overheating, detection issues, and resonance risks.
Solution: Provide a low-impedance path to earth and choose one of three grounding techniques—solid grounding (direct to earth for fast fault clearing), resistance grounding (inserts a resistor to limit fault current and reduce equipment stress), or reactance grounding (uses a reactor to limit current and mitigate transients)—weighing each method’s trade-offs (fault current levels, detectability, heating, resonance) and selecting the technique that fits the system’s safety and operational requirements.
Subtopics: Grounding techniques: solid, resistance, reactance (40%), Fault current limitation & protective device coordination (30%), Resonance and transient overvoltage risks (15%), Training/awareness and system selection guidance (15%)

Title: 2016, Season 4 Episode 9, Electrical Work
Problem: Homeowners have recurring electrical concerns: whether slim LED pot lights can be installed under joists, insurance refusing homes with knob-and-tube wiring, safety and legality of multiple sub‑panels off old fuse boxes, and general hazards from old wiring types (fuse panels, knob‑and‑tube, aluminum wiring) plus DIY/permit confusion.
Solution: The show advises replacing unsafe/obsolete equipment (swap fuse panels for modern breaker panels), retrofit or replace knob‑and‑tube (or use approved aluminum‑to‑copper tails and aluminum‑rated devices with antioxidant connectors), use slim LED pot lights with external drivers that fit under joists and allow insulation contact, always obtain ESA permits/inspections and hire licensed electricians, and follow proper connector and installation practices demonstrated on the show.
Topics: Wiring (35%), Safety (25%), Codes & Regulations (20%), Technology (12%), Education (8%)
Subtopics: Panel & subpanel upgrades (20%), Knob‑and‑tube replacement/retrofit (18%), Pot lights & LED retrofit installation (15%), Electrical safety / fire & shock risk (15%), Inspections, permits & ESA compliance (12%), Insurance implications for old wiring (8%), Aluminum wiring connectors and anti‑oxidant practice (6%), Energy‑efficient lighting choices (6%)

Title: Whole House Load Calculations ALL Steps All Videos. NEC Electrical Exam Prep Compilation Article 220
Problem: Learners need to accurately calculate whole‑house electrical load per NEC Article 220 to size the service, main breaker, feeders and conductors, including correct use of demand factors, rounding rules, table selection, and which loads to include or omit.
Solution: A step‑by‑step instructional method using NEC tables and rules: use 3 VA/ft² (nominal voltages) plus 4500 VA for two small‑appliance + one laundry circuits, apply demand factors (220.42, 220.54, 220.55, 220.60 and others), use minimums (e.g., dryer 5000 VA), apply appliance‑specific multipliers (75% rule for 4+ fixed appliances), handle ranges and HVAC per table notes, perform rounding once at the end, and verify with worked examples and practice quizzes; content is delivered in video lessons and offline USB/MP3 resources.
Topics: Education (35%), Codes & Regulations (30%), Planning (20%), Wiring (10%), Technology (5%)
Subtopics: Exam preparation & instructional examples (35%), NEC Article 220 load calculation rules and tables (30%), Service/feeder sizing and demand‑factor application (20%), Conductor/main breaker sizing concepts (10%), Digital delivery (video/USB/MP3) and study tools (5%)

Title: Load Calculation for Basement Electrical
Problem: Improper or undersized basement electrical load calculations and circuit planning leading to trip-prone circuits, wrong wire/breaker sizing, cramped routing, and potential code noncompliance.
Solution: Performed a detailed load calculation using NEC guidance (article 220/210), counted openings/outlets, accounted for dedicated loads (bath heaters, microwave, fridge, disposals, exercise equipment, brewing), increased VA/sq ft from 3 to ~5 where appropriate, selected proper wire gauges and breaker sizes (12/20A where needed, THWN in conduit outdoors), planned panel/subpanel capacity, used AFCI/GFCI and labeled circuits, improved routing practices, and advised when to hire a pro.
Topics: Wiring (30%), Codes & Regulations (25%), Planning (20%), Safety (10%), Tools (8%), Education (7%)

Title: Three Phase Electricity Basics and Calculations electrical engineering
Problem: Clarify how three-phase electricity is generated and measured, explain phase vs line voltages, RMS/peak relationships, cycles/hertz, and how to calculate and plot three-phase waveforms.
Solution: A tutorial-style walkthrough combining theory and demonstrations: show generator coil operation producing sine waves and 120° phase shifts; explain RMS and peak voltage (Vmax = VRMS·√2); demonstrate measurements with multimeter, clamp meter and power analyzer; calculate instantaneous voltages and RMS values step-by-step (using Excel) and show Y/star connection and how phase and line-to-line voltages relate. Safety and competency warnings included.

Title: Electrical Load Calculation Mobile Homes, RV &BoatYards 10 12 12
Problem: Size the main distribution equipment (service/panel, overcurrent device, feeders, neutrals, bonding jumper, grounding electrode conductor and conduit) for multiple-site installations (manufactured/mobile‑home park, RV park, marina) using NEC demand factors and ampacity rules.
Solution: Step through NEC tables to (1) determine unit loads (16 kVA per manufactured home, kVA per RV site, receptacle loads for marina), (2) apply the applicable demand/diversity factors to get total kVA, (3) convert kVA to amperes for the system voltage, (4) select panel/overcurrent sizes (move to switchboard >600 A), (5) size feeders and parallel conductors (parallel when >400 A), (6) size neutral with neutral‑derating rules (>200 A), (7) check 1,100 kcmil threshold for bonding jumper (apply 12.5% if exceeded), (8) size grounding electrode conductor from aggregated conductors using Table 250.66, and (9) size conduits using conduit‑fill/calculator and pick appropriate THHN/THHW conductors.
Topics: Education (35%), Wiring (30%), Codes & Regulations (20%), Planning (10%), Tools (5%)
Subtopics: Teaching load‑calculation methodology & worked examples (20%), Classroom demonstrations / step‑by‑step walkthroughs (10%), Exam/test prep and cheat‑sheet strategy (5%), Conductor sizing & ampacity selection (8%), Paralleling conductors and termination practice (6%), Neutral sizing and derating rules (>200 A) (5%), Grounding electrode conductor & main bonding jumper sizing (4%), Panel and overcurrent device selection (4%), Conduit sizing and conduit‑fill calculations (3%), NEC demand factor tables (articles 550/553/557, etc.) (8%), NEC ampacity and conductor tables (310, 310.15, 310.16) (7%), Specific code checks (1100 kcmil threshold, 12.5% rule, 250.66) (5%), Site distribution design for mobile/RV/marina parks (6%), Load balancing across legs/phases (4%), Use of handheld calculators / conduit‑fill tools (3%), Practical tips for conductor handling/terminations (2%)

Title: Electrical Blueprints - Identifying Circuits and Homeruns
Problem: Determining which lighting and receptacle symbols on the plans correspond to specific panel circuits, what breaker and wire sizes to use, and how to route/group those circuits for installation and estimating.
Solution: Read the plan callouts (e.g., A139) to locate the matching panel and circuit on the panel schedule, note breaker size, phase and volt-amp load to select conductor size (20A → #12), then plan conduit/home‑run and J‑box placement to group adjacent circuits and route back to the panel; also use panel schedule details (MLO/MCB, AIC, voltage/phase) for estimating and installation decisions.

Title: Learn How To Read ELECTRICAL Drawings
Problem: Difficulty understanding and digesting a complete set of electrical construction drawings — identifying symbols, tracing circuits to panels, coordinating lighting/ceiling and mounting heights, and tying electrical plans into site service, fire/safety and other trades.
Solution: Systematic review workflow: start with a high-level pass of sheet titles and general notes; study the legend/symbols and fixture schedules; cross-reference panel board schedules, circuit IDs and riser diagrams to trace feeders and branch circuits; review detail sheets for conduit, transformer grounding and mounting/installation sequencing; and coordinate electrical mounting heights and ceiling/grid requirements with architectural drawings and specifications.

Title: How to read an electrical diagram Lesson #1
Problem: Learners have difficulty reading electrical diagrams—interpreting symbols, tracing power and ground paths, and understanding how switches, relays and the PCM control a load.
Solution: Present a step-by-step diagram-reading method: locate the load, then the power source/fuses and the ground origin; use a consistent color-coding scheme (red = constant power, green = constant ground, orange = switched power, yellow = switched ground); teach the rule that voltage/ground stop at open circuits; explain relay/PCM behavior (electromagnet closes switch to feed the load); and reinforce learning with downloadable blank diagrams and a hands-on coloring exercise using five markers.
Subtopics: Diagram symbols & literacy (40%), Power & ground color-coding rules (25%), Relay/PCM operation and grounding logic (15%), Practical exercise / use of colored markers (10%), Tracing current flow / map-like navigation (10%)

Problem: Translating blueprints into an accurate field layout and completing the lighting/emergency circuit wiring for a floor (locating drops, identifying circuits, and running appropriate cables).
Solution: Followed the printed plans (pink emergency lines and symbols), left coils at each ceiling drop, used 12-3 for emergency circuits and 12-2 for regular lighting, shot MC tubing and pulled wires along the marked rows, and used column/fixture symbols to align real-life locations with the blueprint.
Subtopics: Emergency circuit / 12-3 wiring (40%), General lighting / 12-2 runs (20%), Conduit/MC tube shooting & wire pulling (10%), Blueprint reading & layout planning (20%), Tutorial / how-to walkthrough (10%)

Title: Floor Plan Basics - Using Grid Paper and Electrical Symbols
Problem: How to create a simple, accurate floor plan of a room that includes walls, doors, windows and the locations of electrical switches, outlets and lights.
Solution: Measure walls, doors, windows and distances between features at floor level; note electrical switches, outlets and ceiling lights; transfer measurements to grid paper as an overhead view using a consistent scale (example: 1 box = 1 foot); draw door swings, window placement and mark which switches control which lights; optionally thicken walls and add control labels for clarity.
Subtopics: Floor plan drafting (30%), Measurements & scaling (15%), Instructional steps (20%), Drafting basics/techniques (10%), Electrical feature location (12%), Switch-light mapping (8%), Measuring tools & grid paper (5%)
